Richard Copley said:

Sebastian Ullrich avowed years ago not to touch the thing. It's incredibly weird that he is still the maintainer. (No, I'm not going to subtweet. He's a grown-up.)
It functions mainly as a gravitational well to suck away any enthusiasm that anyone might have.

Sorry if this is off topic, but I wanted to start learning lean4, and I'm an emacs user because I was learning agda. With the current situation of lean4-mode, should I use vs code, or can I stick with emacs?
Emacs lean mode works but it lacks many "interactivity" features.
And has a very annoying bug with unicode symbols: if you use notation for nhds or some other symbols, you may need to restart file every time you type it.
This topic was moved here from #general > Emacs lean4-mode maintenance by Yury G. Kudryashov.
Oskar, you can also use vim instead of VSCode.

Yury G. Kudryashov said:

And has a very annoying bug with unicode symbols: if you use notation for nhds or some other symbols, you may need to restart file every time you type it.

Richard's (and Mekeor's) fork doesn't have this problem because it uses eglot instead of lsp-mode. You lose semantic highlighting, though.
IMO, you can stick with Emacs and open VS Code very occasionally whenever you need some infoview interactivity (it's not often).
Semantic highlighting is a nice feature. It's unfortunate that we need to choose between it and unicode.
@Patrick Massot I would like to keep using emacs
@Mauricio Collares I will try this approach, but to be honest I like interactive features and opening other program outside of emacs feels wrong for my workflow

I understand, but you will have many interactive features available (LSP code actions, the goals pane, etc). It's just that you won't be able to click/hover on infoview terms, which is something I (personally) only miss when profiling code.
Can't I get infoview information outside of hovering over item, like in buffer or something?
You get the goals and messages in a buffer.
Ok, then I will just do lean in emacs
I don't know why my desktop notification doesn't work...

Mauricio Collares said:

[...] you won't be able to click/hover on infoview terms [...]

@Paul Nelson added the ability to inspect expressions and subexpressions in the infoview (those for which the language server provides the information). It's in his fork (and mine). To enable the feature, set lean4-info-plain to nil (or use customize-variable). When you move point in the *Lean Goals* infoview buffer inside a subexpression that has type information, the subexpression gets highlighted and the type information is displayed in the *eldoc* buffer (in the echo area, or in that buffer's own window if it has one).
Mekeor Melire has marked this topic as resolved.
